questions.question: Question 1: What is the most common cause of peripheral neuropathy?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of peripheral neuropathy is diabetes mellitus. The most common pattern of diabetic neuropathy is an ascending, distal symmetric, sensorimotor 
polyneuropathy (glove and stocking type). The most common type of hereditary neuropathy is Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) disease.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 20-year-old man presents with distal leg weakness with no complaints of tingling or 
numbness. On examination, you note reduced muscle stretch reflexes below the knee along 
with the following findings. This condition is associated with which chromosome?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Charcot–Marie–Tooth (CMT) disease. It is most 
commonly associated with chromosome 17. It is the most common type of hereditary neuropathy. The most common variant of this 
condition is CMT1A. It is caused by a duplication of a region on chromosome 17 that includes the 
peripheral myelin protein 22 (PMP22) gene. It usually presents in the first to third decade of life with distal leg weakness, e.g., foot drop with 
no numbness or tingling. There is reduced sensation to all modalities with reduced muscle stretch 
reflexes. Atrophy of the muscles below the knee leads to inverted champagne bottle legs. 1339 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: 1333 
Sold by @itachibot A 32-year-old woman comes with complaints of double vision that gets worse after she reads 
a book or watches television. She also has drooping of the eyelids that gets better after a nap. 
Serology is positive for anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies. Which of the following is more 
commonly associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myasthenia gravis. It is most commonly associated 
with thymic hyperplasia (65% of cases). Thymoma is seen in around 10% of patients with myasthenia gravis. Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular disorder that is characterized by weakness and 
the fatigability of skeletal muscles. It is due to the autoantibody-mediated destruction of 
the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the neuromuscular junction. This consequentially leads to 
a decreased transmission at the neuromuscular (myoneural) junction. There is a characteristic pattern of muscle involvement. Lid and extraocular muscles (diplopia and 
ptosis) are involved early in the disease course. The facial muscles weakness can produce a 
snarling expression, weakness in chewing, and nasal timbre to the voice. Weakness increases with 
repeated use of the muscles and improves with rest. The reflexes are normal in this condition.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 52-year-old man presents with mild ptosis and proximal lower limb weakness. Nerve 
conduction studies show incremental response following brief exercise. Further investigations 
reveal antibodies against presynaptic P/Q voltage-gated calcium channels. Which of the 
following malignancies is associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS). It is 
associated with small-cell lung carcinoma. It is an autoimmune disorder caused by antibodies that block acetylcholine release by inhibiting a 
presynaptic calcium channel. In contrast to myasthenia gravis, rapid, repetitive 
stimulation (muscle activity) results in an increase in muscle response and strength. Patients typically present with weakness of their extremities. In about half the cases, there is an 
underlying malignancy; most often, neuroendocrine carcinoma of the lung (Small cell lung 
carcinoma). The stimulus for autoantibody formation in paraneoplastic cases may be the 
expression of the same calcium channel in the neoplastic cells. 1340 
Sold by @itachibot Patients without cancer often have other autoimmune diseases, such as vitiligo or thyroid 
disease. Treatment consists of drugs that increase acetylcholine release by depolarizing synaptic 
membranes (pyridostigmine), plasmapheresis, and immunosuppressive agents, similar to 
myasthenia gravis.

Question 6: A 51-year-old woman presents with complaints of weakness for 2 months. She reports that 
she has difficulty rising from a chair and combing her hair every morning. Physical exam 
reveals decreased strength in the shoulders and hip. Muscle biopsy findings are shown below. 
What is the likely diagnosis? [Image unavailable] 1334 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The muscle biopsy shows myofiber atrophy accentuated at the edges of the fascicles (perifascicular 
atrophy). The biopsy along with the history is suggestive of dermatomyositis. It is associated 
with perimysial CD4+ cellular infiltrates. Dermatomyositis is an immunologic disease in which damage to small blood vessels contributes to 
muscle injury. 1341 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Viral myositis occurs 1-7 days after a viral infection (HIV-1, coxsackievirus). Muscle 
weakness and tenderness are seen. There are raised CK levels, muscle necrosis without 
inflammation, and positive urine myoglobin.

questions.question:
Question 7: A patient with gastric carcinoma develops proximal muscle weakness. Biopsy findings are 
suggestive of dermatomyositis. Which of the following antibodies are most likely to be 
present in this patient?
questions.explanation:
This patient has developed paraneoplastic dermatomyositis. Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed 
against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic dermatomyositis and 
juvenile dermatomyositis. It presents as gradual, symmetric muscle weakness and myalgias, typically affecting the proximal 
muscles first. Fine movements controlled by distal muscles are affected late in the disease. 
Myopathic changes and elevation in serum creatine kinase levels suggest muscle damage. 1342 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: A patient with muscle weakness is found positive for antibodies against cN1A. What is the 
likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Antibodies to cN1A are seen in inclusion-body myositis. It is the most common inflammatory myopathy in patients >65 years. Patients present with slowly progressive muscle weakness that tends to be most severe in the 
quadriceps and the distal upper extremity muscles. Dysphagia from esophageal and pharyngeal 
muscle involvement can also occur. Laboratory studies usually show modestly elevated creatine kinase levels. Most 
myositis-associated autoantibodies are absent but are positive for antibodies to cN1A.

questions.question:
Question 9: An 8-year-old boy was brought with progressive muscle weakness and walking difficulties. 
The following finding was noted on examination. Genetic testing revealed a dystrophin gene 
mutation. On which chromosome is the affected gene located? 1335 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical history and the image showing pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles are highly 
suggestive of Duchenne's muscular dystrophy. It is an X-linked recessive condition. Duchenne's and Becker's muscular dystrophy are caused by loss-of-function mutations in the 
dystrophin gene on the X chromosome. It is one of the largest human genes. Dystrophin 
provides mechanical stability to the myofiber during muscle contraction. Defects in the complex 
may lead to small membrane tears that permit the influx of calcium, triggering events that result 
in myofiber degeneration. Duchenne's muscular dystrophy is associated with deletions or frame-shift mutations that result 
in the total absence of dystrophin. Immunohistochemical studies for dystrophin show the absence 
of the normal sarcolemmal staining pattern. In contrast, the mutations in Becker's muscular dystrophy typically permit the synthesis of a 
truncated version of dystrophin, which retains some function. Immunohistochemical studies for 
dystrophin show reduced staining.

questions.question: Question 10: NARP syndrome is a?
questions.explanation:
NARP syndrome - Neuropathy Ataxia Retinitis Pigmentosa syndrome is described as 
a mitochondrial function disorder. NARP syndrome is due to a point mutation of the mitochondrial ATPase-6 gene. It has 2 
phenotypes: • NARP • Maternally inherited Leigh syndrome (MILS) It is characterized by moderate, diffuse cerebral and cerebellar atrophy and symmetric lesions of 
the basal ganglia on MRI. The severity of the syndrome corresponds to the mutant mitochondrial 
DNA load in the tissues. 1343 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following are mitochondrial disorders?
questions.explanation:
The following conditions are mitochondrial disorders: • Myoclonic epilepsy with ragged red fibers • Leber hereditary optic neuropathy • Kearns-Sayre syndrome The proteins and tRNAs in the mitochondria may be encoded by 2 sets of genes: • Nuclear genome - Mendelian inheritance patterns • Mitochondrial genome (mtDNA) - maternally inherited, as the oocyte contributes all 
the mitochondria in the embryo Mitochondrial disorders are caused by mutations in the mitochondrial genome. The most consistent pathologic change in skeletal muscle is abnormal aggregates of mitochondria. 
These are seen preferentially in the subsarcolemmal area of affected myofibers, producing 
a ragged red fibers appearance, as shown below.

questions.question:
Question 12: Hypokalemic periodic paralysis is most commonly caused by the mutation of genes encoding 
which of the following ion channels?
questions.explanation:
Hypokalemic periodic paralysis is most commonly caused by the mutation of the genes 
encoding calcium channels (CALCL1A3). It is an autosomal dominant ion channel myopathy with an onset in adolescence. Males are 
usually affected more than females. It presents as proximal muscle weakness. Ocular and bulbar 
muscles are less likely to be involved. 1344

Question 13: In a child diagnosed with myotonia congenita, which of the following ion channel is likely to

questions.explanation:

questions.question: Question 14: Glial hamartia is a feature of which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Glial hamartia are seen in neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF 2). These are microscopic nodular 
collections of glial cells at abnormal locations, often in the superficial and deep layers of the 
cerebral cortex. NF2 is associated with the following: • Bilateral eighth-nerve schwannomas • Multiple meningiomas • Gliomas - typically ependymomas of the spinal cord • Nonneoplastic lesions - schwannosis, meningioangiomatosis, and glial hamartia Option A: NF 1 is associated with neurofibromas of all types, malignant peripheral nerve sheath 
tumors, gliomas of the optic nerve, other glial tumors, hamartomatous lesions, and 
pheochromocytomas. Option C: Tuberous sclerosis is associated with hamartomas within the CNS in the form of cortical 
tubers and subependymal nodules. Other lesions include subependymal giant-cell astrocytoma, 
renal angiomyolipomas, retinal glial hamartomas, pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis, cardiac 
rhabdomyomas, and cysts in the liver, kidneys, and pancreas. Option D: Von Hippel–Lindau disease is associated with hemangioblastomas of the CNS and cysts 
involving the pancreas, liver, and kidneys, and have a propensity to develop renal cell carcinoma 
and pheochromocytoma. NOTE: A hamartia is not considered to be a tumor and is distinct from a hamartoma. A 
hamartoma is a benign neoplasm characterized by tissue misarrangement similar to a hamartia.

questions.question:
Question 15: A pathologist is examining a histopathological slide showing pseudo-Meissner corpuscles. 
This finding is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Focal collections of pseudo-Meissner corpuscles or tactile-like bodies (cells mimicking the 
appearance of Meissner corpuscles) is a feature of diffuse neurofibroma. Note: Meissner corpuscles consist of a cutaneous nerve ending responsible for transmitting the 
sensations of fine, discriminative touch and vibration.

questions.question:
Question 16: An electron microscopic picture of a cut section of a nerve fiber is given. Identify the area 
which will be affected in the most common variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome.
questions.explanation:
The most common variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome is acute inflammatory demyelinating 
polyneuropathy (AIDP). The area affected in this condition is the myelin sheath (marked as 2 in 
the image). 1346 
Sold by @itachibot Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is an acute autoimmune disease that causes fulminant 
polyradiculoneuropathy. It is a T-cell mediated immune response. GBS is usually associated with a history of upper respiratory infection (URI) or acute 
gastroenteritis (AGE) 1-3 weeks prior. The causative organisms may be Campylobacter jejuni, 
cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, and Mycoplasma pneumoniae. It presents with the following features: • Ascending motor paralysis (lower limbs > upper limbs) • Sensory deficits may or may not be seen • Deep tendon reflexes - absent • Transient bladder dysfunction - severe cases • Autonomic manifestations - loss of vasomotor control, postural hypotension, cardiac 
dysrhythmias Histological examination shows inflammation of peripheral nerves, manifested as perivenular and 
endoneurial infiltration by lymphocytes, macrophages, and a few plasma cells. On electron 
microscopy, an early effect on myelin sheaths is seen. There is segmental demyelination induced 
by the actions of activated macrophages. There are several types of Guillain–Barre syndrome: • Demyelinating • Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) - most common • Axonal • Acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN) • Acute motor-sensory axonal neuropathy (AMSAN) • Regional GBS syndromes: Miller–Fisher syndrome (MFS) 1347 
Sold by @itachibot
